_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Policy
     The owners and employees of Cathay Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidential release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidential release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, and/or other authorities, to migrate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the enviroment.

Facility Information
     Anhydrous Ammonia is recieved, stored, and distributed for direct application. The maximun quantity stored would be 149,000 lbs in an 30,000 gallion tank.

The Worst-Case release scenario and the Alternative release scenario
     1. The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the 30,000 gallion tank released as a gas over 10 minuets. The maximun quantity released would be 149,000 lbs, whick represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capicity as limited by design standards. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion of 200 ppm) is 1.16 miles.
     2. The alterative release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a transfer hose. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion of 200 ppm) is .31 miles.

Safety Requirements
     The facility has implemented the provision of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc. and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Healty Administration (OSHA), 29CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

The Five Year Accident Histroy
     There has been no accidential release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years.

The Emergency Response Program
     The facility as provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA TITLE III (EPCRA) and a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA standards, 29 CFR 1910.120, including employee tr

aining.

Planned changes to improve safety
     Safety improvements are an ongoing process at this facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of the safety conditions. There are no additional anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
